author: HCAndersen
text: THE mayor stood at the open window.

author: HCAndersen
text: He looked smart, for his shirt-frill, in which he had stuck a breast-pin, and his ruffles, were very fine.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had shaved his chin uncommonly smooth, although he had cut himself slightly, and had stuck a piece of newspaper over the place.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hark 'ee, youngster!" cried he.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy to whom he spoke was no other than the son of a poor washer-woman, who was just going past the house.

author: HCAndersen
text: He stopped, and respectfully took off his cap.

author: HCAndersen
text: The peak of this cap was broken in the middle, so that he could easily roll it up and put it in his pocket.

author: HCAndersen
text: He stood before the mayor in his poor but clean and well-mended clothes, with heavy wooden shoes on his feet, looking as humble as if it had been the king himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are a good and civil boy," said the mayor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I suppose your mother is busy washing the clothes down by the river, and you are going to carry that thing to her that you have in your pocket.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is very bad for your mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: How much have you got in it?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Only half a quartern," stammered the boy in a frightened voice.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And she has had just as much this morning already?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, it was yesterday," replied the boy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Two halves make a whole," said the mayor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She's good for nothing.

author: HCAndersen
text: What a sad thing it is with these people.

author: HCAndersen
text: Tell your mother she ought to be ashamed of herself.

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't you become a drunkard, but I expect you will though.

author: HCAndersen
text: Poor child! there, go now."

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy went on his way with his cap in his hand, while the wind fluttered his golden hair till the locks stood up straight.

author: HCAndersen
text: He turned round the corner of the street into the little lane that led to the river, where his mother stood in the water by her washing bench, beating the linen with a heavy wooden bar.

author: HCAndersen
text: The floodgates at the mill had been drawn up, and as the water rolled rapidly on, the sheets were dragged along by the stream, and nearly overturned the bench, so that the washer-woman was obliged to lean against it to keep it steady.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have been very nearly carried away," she said; "it is a good thing that you are come, for I want something to strengthen me.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is cold in the water, and I have stood here six hours.

author: HCAndersen
text: Have you brought anything for me?"

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy drew the bottle from his pocket, and the mother put it to her lips, and drank a little.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, how much good that does, and how it warms me," she said; "it is as good as a hot meal, and not so dear.

author: HCAndersen
text: Drink a little, my boy; you look quite pale; you are shivering in your thin clothes, and autumn has really come.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how cold the water is!

author: HCAndersen
text: I hope I shall not be ill.

author: HCAndersen
text: But no, I must not be afraid of that.

author: HCAndersen
text: Give me a little more, and you may have a sip too, but only a sip; you must not get used to it, my poor, dear child."

author: HCAndersen
text: She stepped up to the bridge on which the boy stood as she spoke, and came on shore.

author: HCAndersen
text: The water dripped from the straw mat which she had bound round her body, and from her gown.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I work hard and suffer pain with my poor hands," said she, "but I do it willingly, that I may be able to bring you up honestly and truthfully, my dear boy."

author: HCAndersen
text: At the same moment, a woman, rather older than herself, came towards them.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was a miserable-looking object, lame of one leg, and with a large false curl hanging down over one of her eyes, which was blind.

author: HCAndersen
text: This curl was intended to conceal the blind eye, but it made the defect only more visible.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was a friend of the laundress, and was called, among the neighbors, "Lame Martha, with the curl."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, you poor thing; how you do work, standing there in the water!" she exclaimed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You really do need something to give you a little warmth, and yet spiteful people cry out about the few drops you take."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then Martha repeated to the laundress, in a very few minutes, all that the mayor had said to her boy, which she had overheard; and she felt very angry that any man could speak, as he had done, of a mother to her own child, about the few drops she had taken; and she was still more angry because, on that very day, the mayor was going to have a dinner-party, at which there would be wine, strong, rich wine, drunk by the bottle.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Many will take more than they ought, but they don't call that drinking!

author: HCAndersen
text: They are all right, you are good for nothing indeed!" cried Martha indignantly.

author: HCAndersen
text: "And so he spoke to you in that way, did he, my child?" said the washer-woman, and her lips trembled as she spoke.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He says you have a mother who is good for nothing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, perhaps he is right, but he should not have said it to my child.

author: HCAndersen
text: How much has happened to me from that house!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes," said Martha; "I remember you were in service there, and lived in the house when the mayor's parents were alive; how many years ago that is.

author: HCAndersen
text: Bushels of salt have been eaten since then, and people may well be thirsty," and Martha smiled.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The mayor's great dinner-party to-day ought to have been put off, but the news came too late.

author: HCAndersen
text: The footman told me the dinner was already cooked, when a letter came to say that the mayor's younger brother in Copenhagen is dead."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Dead!" cried the laundress, turning pale as death.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, certainly," replied Martha; "but why do you take it so much to heart?

author: HCAndersen
text: I suppose you knew him years ago, when you were in service there?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is he dead?" she exclaimed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, he was such a kind, good-hearted man, there are not many like him," and the tears rolled down her cheeks as she spoke.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she cried, "Oh, dear me; I feel quite ill: everything is going round me, I cannot bear it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Is the bottle empty?" and she leaned against the plank.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Dear me, you are ill indeed," said the other woman.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Come, cheer up; perhaps it will pass off.

author: HCAndersen
text: No, indeed, I see you are really ill; the best thing for me to do is to lead you home."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But my washing yonder?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I will take care of that.

author: HCAndersen
text: Come, give me your arm.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy can stay here and take care of the linen, and I'll come back and finish the washing; it is but a trifle."

author: HCAndersen
text: The limbs of the laundress shook under her, and she said, "I have stood too long in the cold water, and I have had nothing to eat the whole day since the morning.

author: HCAndersen
text: O kind Heaven, help me to get home; I am in a burning fever.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, my poor child," and she burst into tears.

author: HCAndersen
text: And he, poor boy, wept also, as he sat alone by the river, near to and watching the damp linen.

author: HCAndersen
text: The two women walked very slowly.

author: HCAndersen
text: The laundress slipped and tottered through the lane, and round the corner, into the street where the mayor lived; and just as she reached the front of his house, she sank down upon the pavement.

author: HCAndersen
text: Many persons came round her, and Lame Martha ran into the house for help.

author: HCAndersen
text: The mayor and his guests came to the window.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, it is the laundress," said he; "she has had a little drop too much.

author: HCAndersen
text: She is good for nothing.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is a sad thing for her pretty little son.

author: HCAndersen
text: I like the boy very well; but the mother is good for nothing."

author: HCAndersen
text: After a while the laundress recovered herself, and they led her to her poor dwelling, and put her to bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: Kind Martha warmed a mug of beer for her, with butter and sugar- she considered this the best medicine- and then hastened to the river, washed and rinsed, badly enough, to be sure, but she did her best.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she drew the linen ashore, wet as it was, and laid it in a basket.

author: HCAndersen
text: Before evening, she was sitting in the poor little room with the laundress.

author: HCAndersen
text: The mayor's cook had given her some roasted potatoes and a beautiful piece of fat for the sick woman.

author: HCAndersen
text: Martha and the boy enjoyed these good things very much; but the sick woman could only say that the smell was very nourishing, she thought.

author: HCAndersen
text: By-and-by the boy was put to bed, in the same bed as the one in which his mother lay; but he slept at her feet, covered with an old quilt made of blue and white patchwork.

author: HCAndersen
text: The laundress felt a little better by this time.

author: HCAndersen
text: The warm beer had strengthened her, and the smell of the good food had been pleasant to her.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Many thanks, you good soul," she said to Martha.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now the boy is asleep, I will tell you all.

author: HCAndersen
text: He is soon asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: How gentle and sweet he looks as he lies there with his eyes closed!

author: HCAndersen
text: He does not know how his mother has suffered; and Heaven grant he never may know it.

author: HCAndersen
text: I was in service at the counsellor's, the father of the mayor, and it happened that the youngest of his sons, the student, came home.

author: HCAndersen
text: I was a young wild girl then, but honest; that I can declare in the sight of Heaven.

author: HCAndersen
text: The student was merry and gay, brave and affectionate; every drop of blood in him was good and honorable; a better man never lived on earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was the son of the house, and I was only a maid; but he loved me truly and honorably, and he told his mother of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was to him as an angel upon earth; she was so wise and loving.

author: HCAndersen
text: He went to travel, and before he started he placed a gold ring on my finger; and as soon as he was out of the house, my mistress sent for me.

author: HCAndersen
text: Gently and earnestly she drew me to her, and spake as if an angel were speaking.

author: HCAndersen
text: She showed me clearly, in spirit and in truth, the difference there was between him and me.

author: HCAndersen
text: 'He is pleased now,' she said, 'with your pretty face; but good looks do not last long.

author: HCAndersen
text: You have not been educated like he has.

author: HCAndersen
text: You are not equals in mind and rank, and therein lies the misfortune.

author: HCAndersen
text: I esteem the poor,' she added.

author: HCAndersen
text: 'In the sight of God, they may occupy a higher place than many of the rich; but here upon earth we must beware of entering upon a false track, lest we are overturned in our plans, like a carriage that travels by a dangerous road.

author: HCAndersen
text: I know a worthy man, an artisan, who wishes to marry you.

author: HCAndersen
text: I mean Eric, the glovemaker.

author: HCAndersen
text: He is a widower, without children, and in a good position.

author: HCAndersen
text: Will you think it over?'

author: HCAndersen
text: Every word she said pierced my heart like a knife; but I knew she was right, and the thought pressed heavily upon me.

author: HCAndersen
text: I kissed her hand, and wept bitter tears, and I wept still more when I went to my room, and threw myself on the bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: I passed through a dreadful night; God knows what I suffered, and how I struggled.

author: HCAndersen
text: The following Sunday I went to the house of God to pray for light to direct my path.

author: HCAndersen
text: It seemed like a providence that as I stepped out of church Eric came towards me; and then there remained not a doubt in my mind.

author: HCAndersen
text: We were suited to each other in rank and circumstances.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was, even then, a man of good means.

author: HCAndersen
text: I went up to him, and took his hand, and said, 'Do you still feel the same for me?' 'Yes; ever and always,' said he.

author: HCAndersen
text: 'Will you, then, marry a maiden who honors and esteems you, although she cannot offer you her love? but that may come.' 'Yes, it will come,' said he; and we joined our hands together, and I went home to my mistress.

author: HCAndersen
text: The gold ring which her son had given me I wore next to my heart.

author: HCAndersen
text: I could not place it on my finger during the daytime, but only in the evening, when I went to bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: I kissed the ring till my lips almost bled, and then I gave it to my mistress, and told her that the banns were to be put up for me and the glovemaker the following week.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then my mistress threw her arms round me, and kissed me.

author: HCAndersen
text: She did not say that I was 'good for nothing;' very likely I was better then than I am now; but the misfortunes of this world, were unknown to me then.

author: HCAndersen
text: At Michaelmas we were married, and for the first year everything went well with us.

author: HCAndersen
text: We had a journeyman and an apprentice, and you were our servant, Martha."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, yes, and you were a dear, good mistress," said Martha, "I shall never forget how kind you and your husband were to me."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, those were happy years when you were with us, although we had no children at first.

author: HCAndersen
text: The student I never met again.

author: HCAndersen
text: Yet I saw him once, although he did not see me.

author: HCAndersen
text: He came to his mother's funeral.

author: HCAndersen
text: I saw him, looking pale as death, and deeply troubled, standing at her grave; for she was his mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sometime after, when his father died, he was in foreign lands, and did not come home.

author: HCAndersen
text: I know that he never married, I believe he became a lawyer.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had forgotten me, and even had we met he would not have known me, for I have lost all my good looks, and perhaps that is all for the best."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then she spoke of the dark days of trial, when misfortune had fallen upon them.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We had five hundred dollars," she said, "and there was a house in the street to be sold for two hundred, so we thought it would be worth our while to pull it down and build a new one in its place; so it was bought.

author: HCAndersen
text: The builder and carpenter made an estimate that the new house would cost ten hundred and twenty dollars to build.

author: HCAndersen
text: Eric had credit, so he borrowed the money in the chief town.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the captain, who was bringing it to him, was shipwrecked, and the money lost.

author: HCAndersen
text: Just about this time, my dear sweet boy, who lies sleeping there, was born, and my husband was attacked with a severe lingering illness.

author: HCAndersen
text: For three quarters of a year I was obliged to dress and undress him.

author: HCAndersen
text: We were backward in our payments, we borrowed more money, and all that we had was lost and sold, and then my husband died.

author: HCAndersen
text: Since then I have worked, toiled, and striven for the sake of the child.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have scrubbed and washed both coarse and fine linen, but I have not been able to make myself better off; and it was God's will.

author: HCAndersen
text: In His own time He will take me to Himself, but I know He will never forsake my boy."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the morning she felt much refreshed, and strong enough, as she thought, to go on with her work.

author: HCAndersen
text: But as soon as she stepped into the cold water, a sudden faintness seized her; she clutched at the air convulsively with her hand, took one step forward, and fell.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her head rested on dry land, but her feet were in the water; her wooden shoes, which were only tied on by a wisp of straw, were carried away by the stream, and thus she was found by Martha when she came to bring her some coffee.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the meantime a messenger had been sent to her house by the mayor, to say that she must come to him immediately, as he had something to tell her.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was too late; a surgeon had been sent for to open a vein in her arm, but the poor woman was dead.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She has drunk herself to death," said the cruel mayor.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the letter, containing the news of his brother's death, it was stated that he had left in his will a legacy of six hundred dollars to the glovemaker's widow, who had been his mother's maid, to be paid with discretion, in large or small sums to the widow or her child.

author: HCAndersen
text: "There was something between my brother and her, I remember," said the mayor; "it is a good thing that she is out of the way, for now the boy will have the whole.

author: HCAndersen
text: I will place him with honest people to bring him up, that he may become a respectable working man."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the blessing of God rested upon these words.

author: HCAndersen
text: The mayor sent for the boy to come to him, and promised to take care of him, but most cruelly added that it was a good thing that his mother was dead, for "she was good for nothing."

author: HCAndersen
text: They carried her to the churchyard, the churchyard in which the poor were buried.

author: HCAndersen
text: Martha strewed sand on the grave and planted a rose-tree upon it, and the boy stood by her side.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, my poor mother!" he cried, while the tears rolled down his cheeks.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is it true what they say, that she was good for nothing?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, indeed, it is not true," replied the old servant, raising her eyes to heaven; "she was worth a great deal; I knew it years ago, and since the last night of her life I am more certain of it than ever.

author: HCAndersen
text: I say she was a good and worthy woman, and God, who is in heaven, knows I am speaking the truth, though the world may say, even now she was good for nothing."
